awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Exploring the Transcriptional Regulatory Networks Controlling the Early Stages of Legume Nodulation
awd_abstract_narration:
A group of bacteria called rhizobia convert atmospheric nitrogen to a chemical form available to support growth and reproduction of plants in the legume family. The bacteria establish a symbiotic relationship with their legume hosts, residing in root nodules where specialized structures develop to facilitate the exchange of nutrients between the two partners. This is an economically important process as it reduces the amount of nitrogen fertilizer needed to grow crops and is a key component in sustainable agriculture. Thus, a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms controlling the nodulation process should lead to insights about more effective ways to capture and fix atmospheric nitrogen and to the transfer of this capacity to non-legume plants. One notable achievement in our understanding of legume nodulation is the characterization of the signaling steps that control the infection of the plant root hair cell by rhizobia, the initial step of nodulation. This symbiotic pathway is regulated by almost 2000 genes in legume root hair cells. The investigators will characterize a network of genes essential in controlling the early stages of nodulation. In addition to its impact on legume research, the broader impacts of this project include the development of unique educational programs dedicated to Oklahoma high-school and undergraduate students from under-represented groups, promoting strong integration between research and education.

This CAREER project is built on the hypothesis that regulatory networks directly under the control of one or several transcription factors of the symbiotic pathway orchestrate the proper activation and timing of gene expression in root hair cells in response to rhizobia. Specifically focusing on the Nodulation Signaling Pathway1 (NSP1) regulatory network, this project will address two key questions: What is the identity of the soybean and medicago root hair genes directly under the control of NSP1? What are the protein complexes asscociated with NSP1 and how do they control the expression of root hair genes in response to rhizobial inoculation? To answer these questions, the investigators will 1) characterize the soybean root hair genes directly under the control of the transcription factors GmNSP1a and b in response to Bradyrhizobium japonicum through high-throughput sequencing technologies and by applying DamID-seq or ChIP-seq methods, 2) identify the protein partners of the GmNSP1a and b in root hair cells inoculated with B. japonicum by co-immunoprecipitation of the protein partners in root hair cells upon rhizobia inoculation; 3) validate the conservation of the root hair gene regulatory networks between soybean and Medicago truncatula, the model legume.

por.por_cntn:
Nodulation underlies the fixation of atmospheric nitrogen via symbioses of soil-borne microorganisms (i.e. rhizobia) with leguminous plants. This is an economically and environmentally beneficial biological process. This CAREER project focused on better characterizing the transcriptional response of the plant during the early stages of its infection by rhizobia.

 

Rhizobial infection of leguminous plants starts with the chemical recognition of the two partners leading to morphological, physiological, and molecular changes of the plant root hair cells, root epidermal cells characterized by their polar elongation. Among these changes, a signaling cascade controls the infection of the plant root hair cell by rhizobia and ends with the activation of the expression of several transcription factors such as Nodulation Signaling Pathway1 (NSP1). Ultimately, the bacteria will infect the root hair cells and then the dividing cortical root cells through the development of an infection thread.

 

As part of this NSF-CAREER project, the main objective was to reveal the transcriptomic programs and gene regulatory networks controlling the infection of the soybean (Glycine max) and barrel medic (Medicago truncatula) root hair cells by rhizobia including those under the control of the NSP1 proteins. As part of this project, we validated the role of FW2.2-like 1 (FWL1) protein, a plasma membrane microdomain-associated protein, as a key regulator of the early stages of infection of the soybean plant by rhizobia. We are currently finalizing the functional characterization of a second member of the soybean FWL family during the nodulation process. When analyzing the transcriptomic programs differentially regulated on legume root hair cells in response to Rhizobia, one of the main challenges of this project resided in the low number of root hair cells responding to, interacting with, and infected by rhizobia. To overcome this challenge, we developed, validated, and applied a single-cell resolution transcriptomic approach allowing the capture of the unique programs activated and repressed in each root hair cell of infected and mock-infected plants. This approach led to the identification of the M. truncatula genes differentially expressed in a subset of the root hair and cortical cells 48 hours after rhizobia inoculation. We are currently analyzing similar results collected from inoculated and mock-inoculated soybean root 48 hours after rhizobia inoculation. These data will allow the comparative analysis of the transcriptional responses of two model legume species upon rhizobia inoculation.

 

This NSF-CAREER project also supported the development of a very successful outreach program, the “Research Experience for High School Students” (REHSS) program, with Oklahoma and Nebraska high schools. This outreach program has two components. First, “The Plant Biotechnology Workshop” provides opportunities to high school students, including those of rural communities, to be exposed to plant molecular biology and modern biotechnologies. Over 750 high school students from seven different high schools benefited from this program. Second, 70 students were enrolled in two-month internships in laboratories from the University of Oklahoma and Nebraska-Lincoln as part of “The Summer Research Experience” program. To enhance the experience of the students, the “The Summer Research Experience” program supported internships in laboratories with different expertise including molecular biology, biochemistry, ecology, plant biology, animal biology, microbiology, or geology.
